page.title: 03Landscape, Drainage
page.content: As the area is low_lying the landscape is governed by drainage. Some fields still have regular undulations known as gripes to facilitate drainage into the ditches. The ditches and footbridges are maintained by the farmers. The Inland Drainage Board has responsibility for land up to 8 feet above known high tide level, so they maintain the rhines into which ditches drain. Rhines flow west and discharge into the Chessil Rhine and onto the Severn. The rhines are cleared of weed yearly. Most are below land level but Tockington Mill Rhine is a high level rhine carrying water across the area. Where a high level crosses a low level rhine there are coffer goughs, syphonic arrangements to maintain water level. There are two in this area.
